Peter, if you don't mind my asking, what kind of work do you do for a 
livi=
ng?  Is your work with NEAT/HyperNEAT in your spare time or does 
it have a=
 relation to your job?  I'm curious since you got it all 
implemented so fa=
st that it's impressive.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervens=
ki" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> An interesting thing to mention, yes=
terday I was playing with my 
> Humans experiment. I took a CPPN that produ=
ces a CTRNN exhibiting 
> a "mexican wave" behaviour. I scaled up the subst=
rate to 
> approximately 200 hidden nodes. The "mexican wave" pattern was 
=
> preserved! And more, even the direction of the wave was the same! 
> 
> -=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote=
:
> >
> > Hello, 
> > 
> > I was just thinking about NERO. I suddenly made =
the connection 
> between 
> > the sensor placements and the substrates for=
 the robot experiment 
> in 
> > D'Ambrosio's paper. It is so similar. So I=
 begin to think.. What 
> about 
> > NERO, but using HyperNEAT? The substra=
tes can be made 
geometrically 
> > similar to the.. enivonment, you know w=
hat I mean. 
> > I will try to implement a 2D version of something similar =
to 
NERO, 
> but 
> > with leaky integrator neurons, because there every no=
de has a 
bias 
> and 
> > I don't have to care about where to place the bi=
as unit in the 
> > substrate. 
> > Besides, I have the following idea. Dur=
ing evolution, in the 
first 
> > generations (in the rtNEAT case, the firs=
t N minutes of 
evolution), 
> the 
> > substrates will be simple, with low=
 node counts. Then, given a 
> > threshold (num. of generations/time), the =
program will 
> automatically 
> > scale up the substrate to a higher densi=
ty. 
> > 
> > Any suggestions/ideas about that? 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
